text: so actually we
know uh a lot about the early stages of
auditory processing we know that there
are sound waves uh they are propagated
down into a structure in your ear called
the CIA uh within that structure there
are uh neurons that are exquisitly
sensitive to minute uh changes in in
pressure they're sensitive to those
changes at different frequencies so
actually what your CIA does is it acts
as what's called a spectral analyzer so
there are some neurons that are
sensitive to low frequency sounds and
other neurons that are sensitive to
Middle frequency and other neurons that
are sensitive to high frequency and each
one of those is coded separately uh
along a set of of nerve fibers then
they're passed through a bunch of stage
ages uh in your auditory system before
they get to your cortex so the last
stage uh so so I'll say that what's
interesting is that the the stages of
processing a sound are incredibly
different as you might imagine from the
stages of processing a visual scene so
those stages that I just told you are
designed for processing physical
vibrations between the ranges in a human
of 20 Herz to 20 khz we have eyes that
aren't responsible for transducing uh
sound vibrations but rather light and
you know the structure of the retina is
also well understood there are photo
receptors that pick up uh photons and
transmit those signals but what's
interesting is that once those signals
get processed or if you like
pre-processed they end up in structures
that now look remarkably similar a
structure called the thalamus and
there's a part of the thalamus that
receives input from the auditory system
another part of the thalamus that uh
receives input from the from the visual
system from the retina and then uh after
it gets to the thalamus it goes to the
cortex and within the cortex the signals
uh now look very similar and so what
what what seems to be the case is that
there's this
pre-processor uh in the uh on the
auditory side on the visual side and
actually all your sensory modalities
that's highly specialized for the kind
of sensory input we have but then it
converts it into sort of a standard form
that gets passed up to the cortex so
what we actually believe is that if that
the mechanisms of auditory attention are
actually not probably fundamentally
different from the mechanisms of any
other kind of attention including visual
attention
